EP Examinations is the function designated with the responsibility to if a retirement plan is qualiﬁed under IRC
and the underlying and therefore, exempt from tax under IRC
EP Examinations audit program’s primary objective is regulatory, continued qualiﬁcation of employee beneﬁt plans (Policy Statement

). Examinations selects and examines returns to: a. Promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance with the tax laws plan qualiﬁcation. b. Determine qualiﬁed plans’ extent of compliance and the causes of compliance with the tax laws. c. Determine whether such plans meet the applicable qualiﬁcation ments in operation. Under Policy Statement
, EP agents and managers are: a. Given broad authority to consider and weigh conﬂicting information, and opinions.
a. Promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance with the tax laws plan qualiﬁcation. b. Determine qualiﬁed plans’ extent of compliance and the causes of non
compliance with the tax laws. c. Determine whether such plans meet the applicable qualiﬁcation require
ments in operation.

b. To use professional judgement according to examination standards to make ﬁndings of fact and apply the IRS’s position on issues of law to determine the correct tax liability. c. (12-04-2018) Overview of Fraud Procedures
This IRM addresses the procedures Employee Plans (EP) employees should follow when fraud becomes an issue on audit completed by EP Examinations.
Fraud Procedures
) The EP SME, TE/GE Fraud Specialist, and FTA provide EP Examinations agents and managers with guidance and assistance in developing cases fraud potential. (
) Unless stated otherwise, this IRM is written to provide instructions to EP agents. (
) References to “agent” or “manager” in this section refer to EP agents and their managers unless otherwise speciﬁed. (
) IRM
, Fraud Handbook, must be considered in conjunction with this section since it encompasses a broad range of information regarding fraud is not included in the procedures contained in this IRM. (
) This IRM section is intended to provide supplemental information speciﬁc fraud and fraud related activities in EP and is not intended to replace IRM
, Fraud Handbook, or IRM
, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, Overview of Form
Procedures. (
) When indicators (signs or symptoms) of fraud are identiﬁed, initiate a sion with your group manager and document your case chronology accordingly. (

) There are numerous indicators of fraud that encompass income, expenses deductions, books and records, taxpayer conduct, methods of and large, unusual and questionable (LUQ) items. A complete list is in IRM
, Indicators of Fraud. (

) INCOME: common indicators of fraud for retirement plans include: • Assets shown as real estate or other assets when in fact it may be commercial business or an income producing venture (legal or • Concealment of bank accounts, brokerage accounts, and other • Failure to deposit receipts to trust accounts (such as employee deferrals, employer contributions, rollovers, etc.). • Failure to ﬁle a tax return (such as Form
-T, Exempt Business Income Tax Return), especially when there is substantial taxable income for a period of several years. (

) EXPENSES: common indicators of fraud for retirement plans include: • Annual funding of a deﬁned beneﬁt plan based upon unreasonable actuarial assumptions leading to excessive tax deductions. • Claiming ﬁctitious deductions as retirement plan contributions or expenses of the trust. • Diversion of funds by trustees or ﬁduciaries of employee plans. • Failure to pay terminated and retired participants their beneﬁts. • Fictitious or deceased participants receiving distributions from plans or the denial of the receipt of trust assets. • Improper expenses paid by trust officials. • Substantial amounts of personal expenditures paid with trust funds. • Substantial overstatement of retirement plan deductions or ment of contributions (underfunded plans). (
) BOOKS AND RECORDS: common indicators of fraud for retirement plans include: (

BOOKS AND RECORDS: common indicators of fraud for retirement plans
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

• Amounts on return, in books and other source records that do not reconcile. • Backdated or postdated plan documents, false applications for beneﬁts, loans, hardship distributions or other false documents. • Checks made payable to third parties endorsed by plan ﬁduciaries or checks made payable to consultants and cashed by the plan ﬁduciaries or trustees. • Failure to keep adequate records, concealment/destruction of records, or refusal to make certain records available. • False statements used to obtain minimum funding waivers or tion letters, which may lead to a referral for examination. (

) TAXPAYER CONDUCT: common indicators of fraud for retirement plans include: • Any breach of a ﬁduciary relationship, such as salary payments in excess of the amount indicated in the service provider agreement or receiving of kickbacks related to some aspect of plan operation. • Attempts to hinder the examination. Example: Failure to answer pertinent questions, repeated of appointments, refusal to provide records, threatening potential witnesses including the agent, or assaulting the agent. • Attempts to bribe an agent. • Backdating of applications and related documents in order to qualify for tax deductions a year early. • Destruction of books and records, especially just after the start of the examination. • Fabricating documents in an attempt to substantiate false, material statements. • Failure to follow the advice of accountant, attorney or third party admin- istrator. • Failure to make full disclosure of relevant facts to a return (including an information return) preparer. • False statement about a material fact involved in the examination. • Involvement by a convicted felon as a trustee or service provider to a retirement plan. • Involvement in prohibited transactions, as deﬁned in IRC
• Making false statements on Employee Plans Determination Letter Appli- cations or on Forms

, Annual Return/Report of Employee Beneﬁt Plan. • Submitting a false affidavit. • Transfer of assets for purposes of concealment or diversion of funds by officers, trustees or representatives. • Willful and intentional failure to execute pension plan amendments. (

) METHODS OF CONCEALMENT: common indicators of fraud for retirement plans include: • Assets placed in the names of others rather than in the trust’s name. • Close relationship between parties to an asset transfer. • Failure to deposit contributions to the proper account. • Inadequacy of consideration related to asset purchases. • Transactions surrounded by secrecy. If your manager agrees that there are indicators of fraud, contact the EP to get advice and to discuss the indicators of fraud.
Reminder: Timely and appropriate actions are very important if the potential for fraud exists.

If the EP SME concurs that there are indicators of fraud, then the EP SME arrange a meeting with the assigned FTA for your geographic location to discuss the issue(s). If the FTA agrees that the potential for fraud exists, then the EP SME will arrange a four-way conference call or meeting with you, your manager, the SME and the FTA to discuss the case. ) All criminal investigations involving cooperating EP agents are subject to mandatory quarterly (four-way) conferences. (
) The CI SSA should contact the EP group manager to schedule the four-way conference. (
) The EP group manager may also request a four-way conference when one due. The conference may be jointly held with other EFUs. (
) The four-way conference must be attended by the SSA, SA, EP group manager and cooperating EP agent. The FTA and EP SME may also when necessary. (
) The purpose of the four-way conference is to review the status of the investigation and plan actions required of the cooperating EP agent and SA. (
) Appropriate follow-up should be done periodically to ensure prompt of the investigation and proper use of resources. (
) The inclusion of the FTA and EP SME does not override the EP group manager’s responsibility for case and resource oversight. (

The Government carries the burden of proof for the omission of gross income.

The Government carries the burden of proof for the omission of gross income. a. TE/GE Division Counsel must formally approve the use of any six-year statute and the Counsel memo approving its use must be included in the administrative case ﬁle. b. Only reportable income, omitted from the return, is included in the com- putation. c. Omitted or overstated deductions and expenses are not considered in computation. For purposes of IRC

(e) gross income includes, but is not limited to, the following: a. Gross income in the case of a trade or business means the total of the amounts received or accrued from the sale of goods or services (gross receipts), without reduction for the costs of those goods or services. b. Gross income, other than from the sale of goods or services in a trade or business, has the same meaning as provided under IRC

(a), and includes the total amounts received or accrued, to the extent required to be shown on the return. When the amounts received or accrued relate the disposition of property, gross income means the excess of the amount realized from the disposition of the property over the cost or other basis of the property. )(c). c. In the case of a partner in a partnership, gross income for this computa- tion includes his or her share of the partnership’s gross income, not the net ﬂow-through. Thus, a copy of the partnership return is required to correctly determine the taxpayer’s gross income. d. In the case of a shareholder in an S corporation, gross income for this computation includes his or her share of the S corporation’s gross income, not the net ﬂow-through or distributed and undistributed taxable income. Thus, a copy of the S corporation return is required to correctly determine the taxpayer’s gross income. e. Only the net amount of capital gain (sales price less cost basis) on a transaction is included in the computation. Also, capital losses on trans- actions may not reduce gross income because some capital losses are not netted against capital gains. f. In the case of a taxpayer deemed to be in the trade or business of stock, the gross income for this calculation is the gross sales price of the stock (no reduction for cost basis). g. The taxable portions of pension and annuity distributions are gross income. An amount is not considered as omitted from gross income if information suffi- cient to determine the nature and amount of the item is disclosed in the including any schedule or statement attached to the return.

There must be an assigned Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent and group manager who handle the grand jury aspects of the case. The Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent assists the Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) with the consideration, review and resolution of

technical issues related to the criminal charges being investigated. The EP agent conducting the civil examination can become the Grand Jury EP Agent. However, the agent would not be permitted to complete the civil examination once the case comes out of grand jury suspense. The case would have to be re-assigned to a different agent group manager since both were privy to grand jury material. The names of all participants in the grand jury matter, including the ing Grand Jury EP Agent and group manager, will appear on the “
(e) list” official list ﬁled with the court of those individuals authorized to view tion protected by Fed. R. Crim. P.
(e). Evidence obtained during a grand jury investigation is protected under the secrecy provisions of Rule

(e) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. Therefore, in a civil case, the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent cannot disclose any information obtained by the grand jury, unless that grand jury formation has been made a matter of public record. The Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent’s workpapers will be part of the Cl grand jury ﬁles. a. The ﬁles will not be available for the civil EP examination activity a Rule

(e) court order. b. Workpapers, however, admitted or referenced and speciﬁcally in open court, are available for use in the context of a civil settlement. Grand jury materials should be kept in a separate work area, inaccessible other IRS personnel not assisting the AUSA. The Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent is prohibited from gathering useful only in a civil proceeding. a. The Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent must be aware of the civil mation received or developed during the grand jury investigation the civil information can be used when the case is sent/returned to ﬁeld for the civil case resolution. b. Civil information is that information which is a matter of public record, was obtained prior to the convening of the grand jury or was of the grand jury. The Field EP Agent is allowed to use this civil tion in the civil examination. c. One of the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent’s most important bilities is to ensure this information is gathered and made available for the Field EP Agent’s successful resolution of the civil side of the case. The second stage of the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent’s involvement is the Indictment Stage. An indictment is the formal document identifying the grand jury’s charges against the defendant. The indictment is a matter of public record.

) The second stage of the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent’s involvement is the Indictment Stage. An indictment is the formal document identifying the grand jury’s charges against the defendant. The indictment is a matter of record. a. The Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent, in cooperation with the AUSA, should include complete civil assessment information in the indictment. b. Depending on the charges alleged in the indictment, the AUSA may or may not be able to include this information in the indictment. c. If the case does not go to trial, the next opportunity for the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent to ensure that civil assessment information is preserved is during the plea agreement stage. (

) The third stage of the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent’s involvement is the Plea Agreement Stage. a. Even though the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent usually does not ticipate in this stage, it is important that the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent convey to the AUSA the importance of including speciﬁc civil as- sessment information in the plea agreement. b. Plea negotiations generally result in the defendant pleading guilty to lesser charges. c. If there was limited disclosure of civil information in the indictment, the absence of speciﬁc civil assessment information in the plea agreement may result in the Field EP Agent not having enough non-grand jury mation to propose adjustments, make assessments, address plan or provide information needed for the collection of taxes. d. Thus, the defendant may receive a criminal sentence but the plan may not be addressed or the defendant may not pay any tax and penalties due to lack of information in the public record. e. If speciﬁc civil assessment information is not made a matter of public record through the indictment or plea agreement, the last opportunity to achieve this objective is during formal sentencing proceedings. (

) The fourth stage of the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent’s involvement is Formal Sentencing Proceedings Stage. a. There are many statements and documents entered into the public record during this stage. b. One of the most important documents entered in the public record is Government’s Version of the Facts. This document is often read into the record by the prosecuting attorney. This document usually summarizes what the government would have proven if the case had gone to trial covers years and/or charges to which the defendant did not plead. c. Because the Federal Sentencing Guidelines advise that the entire loss the government be disclosed, including years not included in the plea agreement or indictment when sentencing an offender on a tax charge, the Cooperating Grand Jury EP Agent should request the AUSA read information into the record. This is necessary because this information often sealed as part of the probationary report. Example 2:
qualiﬁed plan’s trust purchased a house and property. The sole of the qualiﬁed plan’s sponsor is also the plan and a plan participant. He and his family live in the house

A qualiﬁed plan’s trust purchased a house and property. The sole shareholder/president of the qualiﬁed plan’s sponsor is also the plan trustee and a plan participant. He and his family live in the house and use trust funds to pay for personal living expenses. He does not report any tax consequences from his use of the trust’s assets. The shareholder/president did not seek advice from a pension professional to determine the consequences of his actions or how to resolve the issue. The sole shareholder/president is a plan ﬁduciary who knowingly used trust funds for his personal gain and failed to report the income tax consequences stemming from his use of the trust funds.
